articles.title: Radius Server
articles.description:
RADIUS serves as a cornerstone in network security, primarily used in scenarios where secure access to a network is a priority. This report delves into the fundamentals of RADIUS, its main components, their roles, and the architecture used in a practical context.

Main Files and Their Roles

  • clients.conf: This file is used to define trusted RADIUS clients or Network Access Servers (NAS) that can communicate with the RADIUS server. It specifies client IP addresses, shared secrets, and other details for secure communication.
  • users File: The 'users' file is where individual user accounts and their attributes are defined. It includes usernames, authentication credentials (such as passwords or certificates), and specific attributes that determine user access rights.
  • radiusd.conf: This configuration file contains various settings related to the RADIUS server's behavior and operation. It defines global parameters, such as the location of other configuration files and server behavior.

These files collectively govern the authentication and authorization process within the RADIUS framework, allowing network administrators to control who accesses the network and what resources they can utilize.
